stem: Initially, a reactor is subcritical with the effective multiplication factor (K ) equal to 0.998. After a eff brief withdrawal of control rods, K equals 1.002. The reactor is currently... eff

choices.D: subcritical.

stem: Which one of the following conditions describes a reactor that is exactly critical? NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: K = 1; ΔK/K = 1 eff -667- PWR Test Items

stem: The ratio of the number of neutrons in one generation to the number of neutrons in the previous generation is the...

choices.D: reproduction factor.

stem: The effective multiplication factor (K ) can be determined by dividing the number of neutrons in eff the third generation by the number of neutrons in the __________ generation. NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: fourth -668- PWR Test Items

stem: The effective multiplication factor (K ) describes the ratio of the number of fission neutrons at the eff end of one generation to the number of fission neutrons at the __________ of the __________ generation.

choices.D: end; previous

stem: A thermal neutron is about to interact with a U-238 nucleus in an operating reactor. Which one of the following describes the most likely interaction and its effect on K ? eff NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.A: The neutron will be scattered, thereby leaving K unchanged. eff
choices.B: The neutron will be absorbed and the nucleus will fission, thereby decreasing K . eff
choices.C: The neutron will be absorbed and the nucleus will fission, thereby increasing K . eff
choices.D: The neutron will be absorbed and the nucleus will decay to Pu-239, thereby increasing K . eff -669- PWR Test Items

stem: A nuclear power plant is currently operating at steady-state 80 percent power near the end of its fuel cycle. During the next 3 days of steady-state power operation, no operator action is taken. How will K be affected during the 3-day period? eff

choices.A: K will gradually increase during the entire period. eff
choices.B: K will gradually decrease during the entire period. eff
choices.C: K will tend to increase, but inherent reactivity feedback will maintain K at 1.0. eff eff
choices.D: K will tend to decrease, but inherent reactivity feedback will maintain K at 1.0. eff eff

stem: A 1.5 MeV neutron is about to interact with a U-238 nucleus in an operating reactor. Which one of the following describes the most likely interaction and its effect on K ? eff NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.A: The neutron will be scattered, thereby leaving K unchanged. eff
choices.B: The neutron will be absorbed and the nucleus will fission, thereby decreasing K . eff
choices.C: The neutron will be absorbed and the nucleus will fission, thereby increasing K . eff
choices.D: The neutron will be absorbed and the nucleus will decay to Pu-239, thereby increasing K . eff -670- PWR Test Items

stem: Which one of the following defines K-excess?

choices.D: (1-K )/K eff eff

stem: KNOWLEDGE: K1.09 [2.5/2.7] QID: P1246 (B2048) Which one of the following is a reason for installing excess reactivity (K ) in a reactor? excess NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.A: To compensate for the conversion of U-238 to Pu-239 during a fuel cycle.
choices.B: To compensate for burnout of Xe-135 and Sm-149 during a power increase.
choices.C: To ensure the fuel temperature coefficient remains negative during a fuel cycle.
choices.D: To compensate for the negative reactivity added by the power coefficient during a power increase. -671- PWR Test Items

stem: A reactor is operating at full power at the beginning of a fuel cycle. A neutron has just been absorbed by a U-238 nucleus at a resonance energy of 6.7 electron volts. Which one of the following describes the most likely reaction for the newly formed U-239 nucleus and the effect of this reaction on K ? excess

choices.A: Decays over several days to Pu-239, which increases K . excess
choices.B: Decays over several days to Pu-240, which increases K . excess
choices.C: Immediately undergoes fast fission, which decreases K . excess
choices.D: Immediately undergoes thermal fission, which decreases K . excess

stem: Which one of the following is a benefit of installing excess reactivity (K ) in a reactor? excess NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.A: Ensures that sufficient control rod negative reactivity is available to shut down the reactor.
choices.B: Ensures that the reactor can be made critical during a peak xenon condition after a reactor trip.
choices.C: Ensures that positive reactivity additions result in controllable reactor power responses.
choices.D: Ensures that the U-235 fuel enrichment is the same at the beginning and the end of a fuel cycle. -672- PWR Test Items

stem: KNOWLEDGE: K1.10 [3.2/3.6] QID: P245 (B248) The shutdown margin determination for an operating reactor assumes the complete withdrawal of…

choices.A: a single control rod of high reactivity worth.
choices.B: a symmetrical pair of control rods of high reactivity worth.
choices.C: a single control rod of average reactivity worth.
choices.D: a symmetrical pair of control rods of average reactivity worth.

stem: A reactor is operating at steady-state 100 percent power with manual rod control about three months from the end of a fuel cycle. During the next two weeks of operation at 100 percent power, the available shutdown margin will... (Assume no operator actions are taken.) NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: initially decrease, and then increase. -673- PWR Test Items

stem: Reactivity is defined as the fractional change in...

choices.D: the effective multiplication factor from criticality.

stem: Which term is described by the following? "The fractional change of the effective multiplication factor from criticality." NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: Reactivity -674- PWR Test Items

stem: With K equal to 0.985, how much reactivity must be added to make the reactor critical? (Round eff answer to the nearest 0.01 %ΔK/K.)

With K equal to 0.987, how much reactivity must be added to make the reactor critical? (Round eff answer to the nearest 0.01 %ΔK/K.) NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: 1.32 %ΔK/K -675- PWR Test Items

stem: In a subcritical reactor, K was increased from 0.85 to 0.95 by rod withdrawal. Which one of the eff following is the approximate amount of reactivity that was added to the core?

With K equal to 0.982, how much positive reactivity is required to make the reactor critical? eff (Round answer to the nearest 0.01 %ΔK/K.) NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: 1.83 %ΔK/K -676- PWR Test Items

stem: With K equal to 0.985, how much positive reactivity is required to make the reactor critical? eff (Round answer to the nearest 0.01 %ΔK/K.)

With K equal to 0.983, how much positive reactivity must be added to make the reactor critical? eff (Round answer to the nearest 0.01 %ΔK/K.) NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: 3.43 %ΔK/K -677- PWR Test Items

stem: Initially, a reactor was shutdown at a stable power level of 2.0 x 10-5 percent. After a small positive reactivity addition, the current stable power level is 3.0 x 10-5 percent. If the initial K was 0.982, eff what is the current K ? eff

choices.D: Cannot be determined without additional information.

stem: A reactor was operating at steady-state 100 percent power with all control rods fully withdrawn and average coolant temperature (T ) at 588°F when a reactor trip occurred. ave After the trip, T stabilized at the no-load temperature of 557°F and all control rods were verified to ave be fully inserted. Given the following information, select the current value of core reactivity. (Assume no operator actions and disregard any reactivity effects of xenon.) Power coefficient = -0.015 %ΔK/K/percent Control rod worth = -6.918 %ΔK/K Moderator temperature coefficient = -0.0012 %ΔK/K/°F NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: -8.418 %ΔK/K -678- PWR Test Items

stem: A reactor is operating at steady-state 90 percent power with all control rods fully withdrawn and average coolant temperature (T ) at 580°F. A reactor trip occurs, after which T stabilizes at the ave ave no-load temperature of 550°F and all control rods are verified to be fully inserted. Given the following information, calculate the current value of core reactivity. (Assume no operator actions and disregard any reactivity effects of changes in xenon-135.) Power coefficient = -0.01 %ΔK/K/percent Control rod worth = -6.918 %ΔK/K Moderator temperature coefficient = -0.01 %ΔK/K/°F NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.D: -7.818 %ΔK/K -679- PWR Test Items

stem: Reactors A and B are identical except that reactor A is operating at steady-state 80 percent power, while reactor B is operating at steady-state 100 percent power. Initial control rod positions are the same for both reactors. How will the shutdown margins (SDM) compare for the two reactors following a reactor trip? (Assume no post-trip operator actions are taken that would affect SDM.) NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.A: Immediately after the reactor trip, reactor A will have the greater SDM.
choices.B: Immediately after the reactor trip, reactor B will have the greater SDM.
choices.C: When sufficient time has passed to allow both cores to become xenon-free, the SDMs will be equal.
choices.D: Within a few minutes after the reactors have tripped, when all parameters have returned to normal post-trip conditions, the SDMs will be equal. -680- PWR Test Items

stem: A reactor is initially operating at steady-state 60 percent power near the end of a fuel cycle when a fully withdrawn control rod suddenly inserts completely into the core. No operator action is taken and the plant control systems stabilize the reactor at a power level in the power range. Compared to the initial available shutdown margin (SDM), the current available SDM is __________; and compared to the initial core K , the current core K is __________. eff eff

choices.D: less negative; the same

stem: Reactors A and B are identical except that reactor A is operating near the beginning of a fuel cycle (BOC) and reactor B is operating near the end of a fuel cycle (EOC). Both reactors are operating at 100 percent power with all control rods fully withdrawn. If the total reactivity worth of the control rods is the same for both reactors, which reactor will have the smaller K five minutes after a reactor trip, and why? eff NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.A: Reactor A, because the power coefficient is less negative near the BOC.
choices.B: Reactor A, because the concentration of U-235 in the fuel rods is higher near the BOC.
choices.C: Reactor B, because the power coefficient is more negative near the EOC.
choices.D: Reactor B, because the concentration of U-235 in the fuel rods is lower near the EOC. -681- PWR Test Items

stem: Reactors A and B are identical except that reactor A is operating near the beginning of a fuel cycle (BOC) and reactor B is operating near the end of a fuel cycle (EOC). Both reactors are operating at 100 percent power with all control rods fully withdrawn. If the total reactivity worth of the control rods is the same for both reactors, which reactor will have the greater K five minutes after a reactor trip, and why? eff NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.A: Reactor A, because the pre-trip reactor coolant boron concentration is lower near the BOC.
choices.B: Reactor A, because the power coefficient adds less positive reactivity after a trip near the BOC.
choices.C: Reactor B, because the pre-trip reactor coolant boron concentration is higher near the EOC.
choices.D: Reactor B, because the power coefficient adds more positive reactivity after a trip near the EOC. -682- PWR Test Items

stem: KNOWLEDGE: K1.14 [3.8/3.9] QID: P7757 A nuclear reactor is shut down with the reactor vessel head removed for refueling. The core is covered by 23 feet of refueling water at 100oF. Source range count rate indicates 100 cps. How will the source range count rate be affected if refueling water temperature increases to 120oF? NRC Generic Fundamentals Examination Question Bank--PWR November 2020

choices.A: The count rate will increase, because the positive effect of increased core neutron leakage more than offsets the negative effect of a smaller K . eff
choices.B: The count rate will increase, because the positive effect of increased core neutron leakage adds to the positive effect of a greater K . eff
choices.C: The count rate will decrease, because the negative effect of decreased core neutron leakage more than offsets the positive effect of a greater K . eff
choices.D: The count rate will decrease, because the negative effect of decreased core neutron leakage adds to the negative effect of a smaller K . eff -683- PWR Test Items

stem: A reactor is currently operating at steady-state 100 percent power near the beginning of a fuel cycle (BOC). When the same reactor is operating at steady-state 100 percent power near the end of a fuel cycle (EOC), how will the BOC and EOC shutdown margins compare? Assume the control rods are fully withdrawn, and the total reactivity worths of the control rods are the same at BOC and EOC.

choices.A: The EOC shutdown margin will be more negative because the power defect will add less positive reactivity immediately after a reactor trip near the EOC.
choices.B: The EOC shutdown margin will be less negative because the power defect will add more positive reactivity immediately after a reactor trip near the EOC.
choices.C: The EOC shutdown margin will be more negative because xenon-135 will add more negative reactivity immediately after a reactor trip near the EOC.
choices.D: The EOC shutdown margin will be less negative because xenon-135 will add less negative reactivity immediately after a reactor trip near the EOC.
